item.title: Getting Setup with Ocaml
item.description:
PreRequisite

This post assumes you have spacemacs already installed.

Install Ocaml

Follow the installation instructions from RealWorldOcaml till you hit the Editors section

After this step you should have a working installation of * ocaml * opam ( the package manager) * merlin * ocamllint * utop

The contents of ~/.ocamllint should be very close to:

## Setting up spacemacs
(* Added by OPAM. *)
let () =
  try Topdirs.dir_directory (Sys.getenv "OCAML_TOPLEVEL_PATH")
  with Not_found -> ()
;;
(* Manually Added*)
#use "topfind";;
#thread;;
#camlp4o;;
#require "core.top";;
#require "core.syntax";;

Project setup

Ensure there is a .merlin file in the same directory as your hello.ml file.

The contents of the .merlin file should be:

PKG core lwt

This doc explains why that statement is needed.

That’s it! now you can open spacemacs and enjoy a full featured IDE experience for ocaml.

item.title: Introducing the uerrors package
item.description:
Internal error messages are usually brief and in a format that is optimized for logging and searching.

An example would be:

> error=true, service=phantom, txid=12345, msg="user not authorized"

While that’s a great error message for developers to search by tags, its not a great error message to display to an end user.

Usually, there’s a translation layer that would take this error message and then return a more user friendly message to the end user. It might look something like:

switch err:
  case ErrInvalidUser:
    umsg := "You are not authorized to perform this action"
  default: 
   umsg := err.Error()
// send umsg down in a response body along with an appropriate statsCode

It’s often hard to find all the code paths and errors an API request could create and then individually, add them to a swtich statement.

This is where uerrors comes in. It offers an easy interface to attach a user-friendly message while creating the original error itself.

Usage

To create a New uerror


err := uerrors.New("pkg: invalid token", "Please renew your API token")

To create an uerror with values available only at run time:


err := uerrors.FromErrors(fmt.Errorf("pkg: txnid=%s, resource=%s", txnid,resource), 
                          fmt.Errorf("Your API request to %s failed. Please contact support if the issue persists", resource))

Constructing an user friendly response:

package main

import (
	"fmt"
	"io"
	"log"
	"net/http"

	"github.com/joshi4/uerrors"
)

func main() {
	http.HandleFunc("/feature", serveFeature)
	http.HandleFunc("/", serveIndex)
	http.ListenAndServe(":6060", nil)
}

func serveIndex(w http.ResponseWriter, req *http.Request) {
	uerr := uerrors.New("example: redirect failed", "Please visit http://localhost:6060/feature if you aren't redirected automatically")
	log.Println(uerr.Error())
	io.WriteString(w, uerr.UserError())
}

func serveFeature(w http.ResponseWriter, req *http.Request) {
	path := req.URL.Path
	uerr := uerrors.FromErrors(fmt.Errorf("example: error=true, endpoint=%s", path),
		fmt.Errorf("Please visit %s a little later", path))
	log.Println(uerr.Error())
	io.WriteString(w, uerr.UserError())
}

item.title: Successfully Avoiding the syslog Package
item.description:
I recently, needed to ship logs from a service written in Go to Papertrail, our chosen log management tool. This seemed straightforward, use the built in syslog package to establish a connection to papertrail and use the io.Writer it returns as the output in the logger. This is where things got interesting.

Before we go further, lets looks at what the above looks like in code:

import (
	"io"
	"log"
	"log/syslog"
	"os"
)

func main() {
	sw, err := syslog.Dial("tcp", "<host>.papertrailapp.com:<port", 0, "tag")
	if err == nil {
		// log to stderr and ship to papertrail
		log.SetOutput(io.MultiWriter(sw, os.Stderr))
	} else {
		log.Println(err)
	}
	// continue with logging as ussual ....
}

Surprisingly, the above program did not work. syslog.Dial reported no errors, logs were output to Stderr, but no logs showed up in papertrail.

After some fiddling I decided to change the protocol to udp. This worked without any problems. Okay, so now that I knew that the problem was somehow with the tcp connection that made things a lot easiser. I quickly, realized that we had set papertrail to only accept tcp connections that are secured with tls.

Digging into the source for the syslog pacakge I found that syslog.Dial estabilishes a connetion with the remote syslog machine via net.Dial and not tls.Dial. Great!, this seems like an opportunity to fix the issue with an upstream patch right ? No! the syslog package is no longer under active developement :(

My colleague pointed me to srslog which fixes exactly this issue. However, it seemed like a very large dependency to bring in just to ship logs to papertrail. By this point I had become familiar with the syslog package and realized that essentially, we were establishing a connection and writing bytes to it. That seems easy ! Why did I need to bring in a large dependency to do that when I can just as easily do this:

func main() {
  sw, err := tls.Dial("tcp", "<host>.papertrailapp.com:port", nil)
	if err == nil {
		// log to stderr and ship to papertrail
		log.SetOutput(io.MultiWriter(sw, os.Stderr))
	} else {
		log.Println(err)
	}
	// continue with logging as ussual ....
}

Now, this worked for us because, we didn’t care about the log priority that you can provide into syslog package and the tag can easily be replaced by setting a Prefix in the logger.

The code ends up being simpler and avoids bringing in a large dependency.
